sourceDesc.p: M.R. James, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge 1912

projectDesc.p: The James Catalogue was digitized then marked up following the TEI P5 Guidelines. The customized model was provided by Giuliano Di Bacco, stored in an ODD file (parkerweb.xml): the latter was written by GDB using ROMA vers. 2.x, with manual adaptations. The ODD file is used as a source to compile the actual schema used to validate the xml: it is advisable to compile it in RelaxNG sintax (parkerweb.rnc) through ROMA.

msDesc.head: Amalarius of Metz, Liber officialis
Amalarius
msDesc.p: Vellum, 283 195 11.1 x 8, ff. 97 + 1, 26, 30, 31 lines to a page. Cent. x (952), in two main hands at least.
Collation: i12 (two cancels) ii8 iii12 (two cancels) iv10 v12 (two cancels) vi10-viii10 ix12 (two cancels) x10 (wants 10): 1 flyleaf.
2 fo.: quid sit or usque dum.
Written at Landevennech in Brittany and afterwards in the library of Christ Church, Canterbury (no. 74 (not 73) in Eastry's Catalogue, Ancient Libraries, p. 24).

msContents.textLang: Latin with some Greek and occasional Breton glosses.
msContents.label: Contents

msItem.head: Amalarius of Metz, Liber officialis

head.title: Collectio Amalarii viri doctissimi de ordine Romanae ecclesiae qui vocatur liber officialis

msItem.ab: Title in capitals
msItem.rubric: Collectio amalarii uiri doctissimi de ordine Romane aeclesiae. qui vocatur liber officialis
msItem.ab: (P. L. CV)
A small letter a (xiv ?) at upper R. corner
Capitula of two books
At top of f. 3r (xiv)
Amalarius de ordine ecc ...
(corner of leaf torn off)
The preliminary letter to Louis the Pious is absent
msItem.incipit: Postquam scripsi libellum qui a mea paruitate uocatur de eclesiastico officio
msItem.ab: (Praefatio altera, belonging to the revised form of the work, P. L. CV 987)

ab.handNote: The hand is a rough and unskilled Carolingian minuscule

msItem.ab: There are fairly numerous interlinear glosses, among which Mr Bradshaw (Collected Papers, p. 472) detected several in Breton. These were printed by Dr Whitley Stokes in Revue Celtique, 1879-80, p. 338

ab.decoNote: Initials are rough, filled with patches of dull red and yellow

ab.handNote: The first obvious change of hand is on f. 13v

msItem.ab: A third hand, much larger and rounder, appears on ff. 37r-38v, thus
Liber I, Capitulum xxxviii. De observatione dierum etc.
ends
msItem.explicit: et sunt omnes dies tamquam dominica
msItem.ab: Then a heading not in the capitula
msItem.rubric: Paulisper de ministratoribus persecutionis Christi quid actum sit uideamus
msItem.incipit: Primus herodes sub quo passi sunt infantes
msItem.ab: On the deaths of the Herods and Pilate and destruction of Jerusalem, mostly from Josephus
msItem.explicit: et qui in sollempnitate pasche dominum crucifixerunt in eadem sollempnitate ab hostibus perirent
et de uico eiusdem tribus ischarioth dominum uendidit
msItem.ab: Liber II, i, de xii lectionibus

ab.handNote: The second hand resumes, and, I think, continues to the end

msItem.ab: At R. upper corner of 39r is xb (? for Christe benedic)
A curiously indented piece has been cut out of the bottom of 39r-39v
f. 47r-47v is mutilated
In the margins, throughout, a large L is frequently written
Cap. lxi or lxii De sexta feria ends
(Liber IV capitulum xvi in P. L. CV)
ΦΙΝΙΘ DΗΩ ΓΡΛΘΙΛΣ ΛΜΗΝ
On f. 97v is the inscription given by Nasmith (corrected by me)

ab.quote:
Anno a natiuitate dni nri ihu xpi dcccclii decima indictione
epactis x(x)ii concurrens iiiitus cum bisexto; ciclo lunari xixo luna xiiiia
pasche ID. aprilis. dies pasche. xiiiio kl. MAI; luna ipsius diei xviiiia;
iussit amadeus diaconus atque habitu monachus hunc
libellum scribere pro sua anima ad utilitatem fratrum: et quicunque
legerit uel scrutatus fuerit aut scripserit eum precor
ut dicat, anima eius requiescat in pace; Sed et quicunque eum
rapuerit uel per uim siue per latrocinium abstulerit a fra
tribus sancti uuingualoei in cuius honore est scriptus ana
thema sit amaranatha in aduentu dni, omnibus fratribus haec atestantibus

msItem.ab: The date is dccccLii but the L is nearly gone
After this is a single leaf (f. 99r) in double columns of 35 lines written apparently on one side only. The script is of much the same character as that of the volume, but smaller
At top in a large hand xii-xiii is
which seems characteristic of Christ Church, Canterbury
The text begins
msItem.incipit: In caena domini reseruetur de ipso corpore domini unde in crastinum
msItem.ab: and ends (De sabbato sancto)
msItem.explicit: Statim sequitur antiphona ad magnificat et oratio n. Et finita sunt ipsa die
msItem.ab: A facsimile of f. 49r and of the colophon is given in the New Palaeographical Society's publication for 1907 (pl. 109)

recordHist.p: markupCheck: checked by SP, BA, CF
